subject: Modern Astrocade Music?
msgSnippet: From time to time, over the past decade or so (maybe even decades), I get interested in listening to 8-bit chiptunes.  I listen to them mostly on YouTube.

Subject: Modern Astrocade Music?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=60931836; y=88vQapjIgbAm3QvuGp1eiFdEdC6clTdliEGRI_-ROnpH3-I

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

From time to time, over the past decade or so (maybe even decades), I get i=
nterested in listening to 8-bit "chiptunes."  I listen to them mostly on Yo=
uTube.  I'm not prejudice: I don't care about the platform that makes the m=
usic.  The C64, the Atari 8-Bit home computers, the Amiga (yeah, baby!) and=
 even the Spectrum have some incredible tunes available.  I like original e=
lectronic music (I'm not much into chiptunes that cover popular songs).  I'=
m always impressed by what some talented musicians are able to push out of =
the older computers (especially the Spectrum).


Each Astrocast podcast has=
 been ending with music.  This has got me interested in Astrocade music aga=
in, especially modern music created on this "dead" platform.  The Astrocade=
 is capable of some great sound effects, and there is even some pretty incr=
edible music made on the platform.  However, unlike these previously mentio=
ned systems, there isn't a modern Astrocade music scene.  I can understand =
this lack of music for the Astrocade.  For a start, there is a severe short=
age of original Astrocade hardware.  However, the Astrocade emulator in MAM=
E plays the sound effects and music pretty well.  So, I guess people could =
create music using the emulator, though it would require the music to be cr=
eated as a cartridge (since, of course, you still can't save from either BA=
SIC).


I'd be extremely interested to see what kind of music people can pu=
mp out of the Astrocade using modern programming methods and machine langua=
ge.  From what little I understand about creating music on an 8-bit platfor=
m, I guess people use "trackers."  No such software exists for the Astrocad=
e.  Is it possible to create it on an 8K cartridge and the Astrocade's 4K o=
f RAM, or does such a program typically require more RAM?  Unlike "proper" =
computer systems, there would be no easy method to load music into the Astr=
ocade... unless the 300-baud interface were used (but that would be a drag =
to use).   What alternative to load music into a cartridge might work for t=
he Astrocade?


If an musicians out there in Bally/Astrocade-land would lik=
e to make some music on the Astrocade then it would be featured on an upcom=
ing episode of the Astrocast podcast.


I haven't got an musical bones in m=
y body... but I do love listening to music.  Am I the only person who would=
 like to see the Astrocade sing again?


Adam

--_000_BLUPR16MB03879C38E9AE15652E5E2807C8820BLUPR16MB0387namp_

<p>From time to time, =
over the past decade or so (maybe even decades), I get interested=
 in listening to 8-bit "chiptunes."  I listen to them mostly=
 on YouTube.  I'm not prejudice: I don't care about the platform that =
makes the music.  The C64, the Atari 8-Bit
 home computers, the Amiga =
(yeah, baby!) and even the Spectrum have some incredible tunes available.&n=
bsp; I like original electronic music (I'm not much into chiptunes that cov=
er popular songs).  I'm always impressed by what some talented musicia=
ns are able to
 push out of the older computers (especially the Spectrum).<=
/p>
<p><br>
</p>
<p>Each Astrocast podcast has been ending with music.&nbsp=
; This has got me interested in Astrocade music again, espec=
ially modern music created on this "dead" platform.  The Ast=
rocade is capable of some great sound effects, and there is even some prett=
y incredible
 music made on the platform.  However, unlike these previ=
ously mentioned systems, there isn't a modern Astrocade music scene.  =
I can understand this lack of music for the Astrocade.  For a start, t=
here is a severe shortage of original Astrocade hardware.  However,
 t=
he Astrocade emulator in MAME plays the sound effects and music pretty well=
.  So, I guess people could create music using the emulator, though it=
 would require the music to be created as a cartridge (since, of course, yo=
u still can't save from either BASIC).</p>
<p><br>
</p>
<p>I'd be extremely=
 interested to see what kind of music people can pump out of the Astrocade =
using modern programming methods and machine language.  From what litt=
le I understand about creating music on an 8-bit platform, I guess people u=
se "trackers."  No
 such software exists for the Astrocade.&=
nbsp; Is it possible to create it on an 8K cartridge and the Astrocade's 4K=
 of RAM, or does such a program typically require more RAM?  Unlike &q=
uot;proper" computer systems, there would be no easy method to load mu=
sic into the
 Astrocade... unless the 300-baud interface were used (but tha=
t would be a drag to use).   What alternative to load music into =
a cartridge might work for the Astrocade?</p>
<p><br>
</p>
<p>If an mu=
sicians out there in Bally/Astrocade-land would like to make some=
 music on the Astrocade then it would be featured on an upcoming episode of=
 the Astrocast podcast.<br>
</p>
<p><br>
</p>
<p><span>I haven't got an mus=
ical bones in my body... but I do love listening to music.  Am I the o=
nly person who would like to see the Astrocade sing again?</span><br>
</p>
=
<p><br>
</p>
<p>Adam<br>
</p>
